facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 85 of 1956 from the judgment and order dated January 8, 1954, of the High Court of Saurashtra at Rajkot in Civil Misc. Application No. 70 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CiVil Appeal No. 85 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 8, 1954, of the High Court of Saurashtra, at Rajkot, in Civil Misc. Application No. 70 of 1952.

facts.text: The appeal was heard on November 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. November 23. The Judgment of the Court was, delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Saurashtra raises an interesting question whether the agarias working in the Salt Works at Kuda in the Rann of Cutch are workmen within the meaning of the term as defined in the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: The appellants are lessees of the Salt Works from the erstwhile State of Dharangadhara and hold a licence for the manufacture of salt on the land.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are lessees of the Salt Works from the erstwhile State of Dharangadhara and also hold a licence for the manufacture of salt on the land. The appellants require salt -for the manufacture of certain chemicals and part of the salt manufactured at the Salt Works is utilised by the appellants in the manufacturing process in the Chemical Works at Dharangadhara and the remaining salt is sold to outsiders.

facts.text: The appellants employ a Salt Superintendent who supervises the Salt Works and the manufacture of salt.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants employ a Salt Superintendent who is in charge of the Salt Works and generally supervises the Works and the manufacture of salt carried on there. The appellants maintain a a railway line and sidings and also have arrangements for storage of drinking water.

facts.text: Salt is manufactured from rain water impregnated with saline matter, operations are seasonal commencing in October at the close of the monsoon and ending in June.

anchor.surface_text: The salt is manufactured number from sea water but from rain water which soaking down the surface becomes impregnated with saline matter. The operations are seasonal in character and companymence sometime in October at the close of the monsoon.

facts.text: The area is parceled out into plots called pattas allotted to agarias, generally the same patta year after year.

anchor.surface_text: Then the entire area is parceled out into plots called pattas and they are in four parallel rows intersected by the railway lines. Each agaria is allotted a patta and in general the same patta is allotted to the same agaria year after year.

facts.text: Appellants pay Rs. 400/- per patta at allotment to meet initial expenses.

anchor.surface_text: If the patta is extensive it is allotted to two agarias who work the same in partnership. At the time of such allotment, the appellants pay a sum of Rs. 400/- for each of the pattas and that is to meet the initial expenses.

facts.text: Agarias level lands, enclose and sink wells; density examined by Salt Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: Then the agarias companymence their work. They level the lands and enclose and sink wells in them. Then the density of the water in the wells is examined by the Salt Superintendent of the appellants and then the brine is brought to the surface and companylected in the reservoirs called companydensers

facts.text: Brine flowed into pattas after acquiring density, transformed into crystals; pans prepared to standards tested by Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: and re- tained therein until it acquires by natural process a certain amount of density. Then it is flowed into the pattas and kept there until it gets transformed into crystals. The pans have got to be prepared by the agarias according to certain standards and they are tested by the Salt Superintendent.

facts.text: Salt crystals tested before collection; collected salt loaded into wagons, transported to depots, tested, paid Rs. 0-5-6 per maund if quality right.

anchor.surface_text: When salt crystals begin to form in the pans they are again tested by the Salt Superintendent and only when they are of a particular quality the work of companylecting salt is allowed to be companymenced. After the crystals are companylected, they are loaded into the railway wagons and transported to the depots where salt is stored.

facts.text: Rejected salt belongs to appellants; agarias cannot remove or sell salt.

anchor.surface_text: The salt is again tested there and if it is found to be of the right quality, the agarias are paid therefore at the rate of Rs. 0-5-6 per maund. Salt which is rejected belongs to the appellants and the agarias cannot either remove the salt manufactured by them or sell it.

facts.text: Final account settlement at end of season, advances and grocery debts deducted, balance paid.

anchor.surface_text: The account is made up at the end of the season when the advances which have been paid to them from time to time as also the amounts due from the agarias to the grocery shop are taken into account. On a final settlement of the accounts, the amount due by the appellants to the agarias is ascertained and such balance is paid by the appellants to the agarias.

facts.text: Agarias work with families, free to engage extra labour and pay them; appellants have nothing to do with it.

anchor.surface_text: The agarias work themselves with their families on the pattas allotted to them. They are free to engage extra labour but it is they who make the payments to these labourers and the appellants have numberhing to do with the same.

facts.text: No prescribed hours of work, no muster roll, no control on hours/days worked.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants do number prescribe any hours of work for these agarias. No muster roll is maintained by them number do they companytrol how many hours in a day and for how many days in a month the agarias should work.

facts.text: No rules for leave or holidays; free to leave if arrangements made.

anchor.surface_text: There are numberrules as regards leave or holidays. They are free to go out of the works as they like provided they make satisfactory arrangements for the manufacture of salt.

facts.text: Disputes arose in about 1950 between agarias and appellants regarding conditions of engagement.

anchor.surface_text: In about 1950, disputes arose between the agarias and the appellants as to the companyditions under which the agarias should be engaged by the appellants in the manufacture of salt.

facts.text: Government of Saurashtra referred disputes by letter dated November 5, 1951 to Industrial Tribunal, Saurashtra State, Rajkot.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Saurashtra, by its letter of Reference dated November 5, 1951, referred the disputes for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Saurashtra State, Rajkot.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held on preliminary issue dated August 30, 1952 that agarias are workmen and reference intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: This question was tried as a preliminary issue and by its order dated August 30, 1952, the Tribunal held that the agarias were workmen within the meaning of the Act and that the reference was intra vires and adjourned the matter for hearing on the merits.

facts.text: Appellants filed Appeal No. 302 of 1952 before Labour Appellate Tribunal of India.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the appellants preferred an appeal being Appeal No. 302 of 1952, before the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India,

facts.text: Appellants moved High Court of Saurashtra in M.P. No. 70 of 1952 under Arts. 226 and 227 to quash the reference.

anchor.surface_text: and having failed- to obtain stay of further proceedings before the Industrial Tribunal pending the appeal, they moved the High Court of Saurashtra in M.P. No. 70 of 1952 under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for an appropriate writ to quash the reference dated November 5, 1951, on the ground that it was without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal dismissed appeal on September 27, 1953 leaving question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the disposal of this writ petition, the appellants obtained stay of further proceedings before the Industrial Tribunal and in view of the same the Labour Appellate Tribunal passed an order on September 27, 1953, dismissing the appeal leaving the question raised therein to the decision of the High Court.

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated January 8, 1954 held agarias are workmen and dismissed the application, granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: By their judgment dated January 8, 1954, the learned Judges of the High Court agreed with the decision of the Industrial Tribunal that the agarias were workmen within s. 2 .s  of the Act and, accordingly, dismissed the application for writ. They, however, granted a certificate under Art. 133 1   c  of the Constitution

facts.text: The facts as found by the Industrial Tribunal are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts as found by the Industrial Tribunal are number in dispute and are as follows.

facts.text: Agarias return to villages for agricultural work at end of season in June.

anchor.surface_text: The manufacturing season companyes to an end in June when the monsoon begins and then the agarias return to their villages and take up agricultural work.

facts.text: Salt Superintendent's evidence: panholders allotted work by oral agreement, no control over hours, days, labour, wages; supervision limited to quality.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the facts narrated above in regard to which there is numberdispute, there was the evidence of the Salt Superintendent of the appellants which was recorded before the Tribunal-  1  1924 1 K.B. 762. The panholders are allotted work on the salt pans by oral agreement.

issues.text: whether the agarias working in the Salt Works of the appellants at Kuda are workmen within the definition of that term in s. 2(s) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in this appeal is whether the agarias working in the Salt Works of the appellants at Kuda are workmen within the definition of that term in s. 2 s  of the Act.

issues.text: whether the status of the agarias was that of independent contractors and not of workmen and whether the State was competent to refer their disputes for adjudication under s. 10 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contested the proceedings on the ground, inter alia, that the status of the agarias was that of independent contractors and not of workmen and that the State was not competent to refer their disputes for adjudication under s. 10 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the High Court exercising its jurisdiction under Arts. 226 and 227 was competent to set aside the finding of fact recorded by the Industrial Tribunal that agarias are workmen

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that such a writ cannot be granted to quash the decision of an inferior court within its jurisdiction on the ground that the decision is wrong. Indeed, it must be shown before such a writ is issued that the authority which passed the order acted without jurisdiction or in excess of it or in violation of the principles of natural justice

holdings.text: the agarias are not independent contractors but workmen within the meaning of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that far from there being noevidence to support the conclusion reached by the Industrial Tribunal there were materials on the record on the basis of which it could come to the conclusion that the agarias are not independent contractors but workmen within the meaning of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows Salt Superintendent supervises and controls all stages of salt manufacture from sinking wells to final testing; satisfies control test and integration into business despite absence of hours/muster; applies s.2(s) definition requiring employment relationship.

holdings.text: the decision of the Industrial Tribunal to the effect that the agarias are workmen within the definition of the term contained in s. 2(s) of the Act was justified on the materials on the record
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's finding supported by evidence of supervision at every stage; High Court correctly affirmed; no lack of evidence warranting interference.

holdings.text: the question whether the relationship between the parties is one as between employer and employee or between master and servant is a pure question of fact

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the relationship between the parties is one as between employer and employee or between master and servant is a pure question of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Weight of authorities (Halsbury, Simmons v. Heath Laundry) holds it pure fact, not mixed; rejects contrary view as based on passing observation.

holdings.text: It is plain that such a writ cannot be granted to quash the decision of an inferior court within its jurisdiction on the ground that the decision is wrong

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that such a writ cannot be granted to quash the decision of an inferior court within its jurisdiction on the ground that the decision is wrong. Indeed, it must be shown before such a writ is issued that the authority which passed the order acted without jurisdiction

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court under Arts. 226/227 cannot interfere with jurisdictional tribunal's fact findings unless unsupported by evidence or jurisdictional error; considerable force in contention, but examined evidence here.

holdings.text: the prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only as to the matter of directing what work the servant is to do but also the manner in which it shall do his work

anchor.surface_text: The principle which emerges from these authorities is that the prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only in the matter of directing what work the servant is to do but also the manner in which he shall do his work

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniformly applied test from authorities (Halsbury, Collins, Mersey Docks); supplemented by integration test where control limited by nature of work; applied to facts showing right of control.

holdings.text: a person can be a workman even though he is paid not per day but by the job

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, abundant authority in England that a person can be a workman even though he is paid not per day but by the job. The following observations of Crompton, J. in Sadler v. Henlock are pertinent in this behalf

holdings.reasoning_summary: Piece-work compatible with master-servant (Sadler v. Henlock, Blake v. Thirst, Halsbury); no distinction from fixed wages if control exists.

holdings.text: a workman does not cease to be such by reason merely of the fact that he gets other persons to work along with him and that those persons are controlled and paid by him

anchor.surface_text: Now a person who agrees himself to work and does so work and is, therefore, a workman does not cease to be such by reason merely of the fact that he gets other persons to work along with him and that those persons are controlled and paid by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal service distinguishes workman from contractor; assistance ok if agrees to work personally (Halsbury, Grainger v. Aynsley); agarias work with families.

holdings.text: These difficulties, however, are not deterrent against holding the agarias to be workmen within the meaning of the definition if they fulfil its requirements

anchor.surface_text: There are no doubt considerable difficulties that may arise if the agarias were held to be workmen within the meaning of s. 2(s) of the Act. These difficulties, however, are not deterrent against holding the agarias to be workmen within the meaning of the definition if they fulfil its requirements.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy difficulties (hours rules inapplicable) irrelevant if facts fit statutory definition; Tribunal to adapt relief accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: Collins v. Hertfordshire County Council  1 .  The test is, however, not accepted as universally correct.

precedents.cited_holding: The greater the amount of direct control... the stronger the grounds for holding it to be a contract of service.

anchor.surface_text: The principle which emerges from these authorities is that the prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only in the matter of directing what work the servant is to do but also the manner in which he shall do his work
